comments:
I tried using protected regions, however I got the error attached at the end of this bug report. The error is caused, because I tried to use (&&) as an ID for a  protected region. It seems to me, that the parenthesis cause the problem. I use the function names of my target language as IDs and in the target language names in parenthesis are allowed and I have no idea, what else to use as the ID for my protected regions.

I've written an unit test for your case. The scanned file is:

-------------
This bug: Also '&&' in protected regions Id must be valid
//PROTECTED REGION ID(&&) ENABLED START
this is an disabled protected region; the content is not protected
//PROTECTED REGION END
-------------

The ProtectedRegionResolver does not complain about this id.

Could it be that you have a closing bracket too in your Id? That would not be valid, since the PR Id is itself encapsulated in brackets. In that case you could use regular expressions with the .replaceAll() method on your Id string.
